ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: It changed my entire worldview for the better.
Critical thinking, ethnographic reading, lots of context about the Middle East, key anthropology ideas

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Both the breadth of the frameworks we learned and the depth of the specific examples the content was grounded in was amazing, in addition to the ways we engaged with it beyond the context of the book. What could be improved is the way discussions are guided. The guiding questions can sometimes be too narrow for undergrads who are largely unfamiliar with these useful frameworks. Chapter by chapter can feel too limiting, but it could be good to just start with sharing general thoughts and feelings in smaller groups for like 10 minutes just to get the ball rolling without the pressures of the entire group discussion. All in all Prof Pepi's classes are definitely one of the best I've ever taken at Yale.

Great course! Strength is Professor Eda Pepi- everybody needs to take a course with Professor Pepi before graduating. Readings were so interesting, discussion was very rich and engaging. One of the best courses I've taken at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This course fundamentally changed the way I view, approach, and reconcile many aspects of my own political and moral thinking. Learning through an ethnographic lens is such a refreshing and vital lens to understand the complexity of human experiences-- war, disparities, racial realities, citizenship, gendered experiences, and everything in between and beyond. There is so much to say about the depth and richness of what I was able to take away from this, but this is definitely a course I enjoyed thoroughly and would recommend.
Yes, everyone should take a course by Prof Pepi before they graduate. Honestly earth-shattering.

Definitely, everybody needs to take a course with Professor Eda Pepi before graduating. Professor Pepi is so engaging and so knowledgeable! The course offered lots of opportunity for growth and was a great environment for learning.
